org.orgName: District Court of the United States

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of MAC FOCK for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
By statute the decision of the Immigration officals is conclusive. Section 25 of the Act of February 20, 1907 (found on page 27 of pamphlet herewith).
The decision is conclusive citizenship is claimed by the person denied entry.
United States v. Tu Joy, 198. U.S. 253; 49 L. Ed. 1040;

The federal courts have no jurisdiction to issue a Writ of Habeas Corpus unless it appears that there has been a radical abuse of discretion or that the Department has plainly erred in the matter of law.
United States v. Tu Joy, 198 U.S. 253; 49 L. Ed. 1040;
Chin You v. United States, 208 U.S.8; 52 L. Ed. 369.
The certificate relied upon by Petitioner is not evidence of citizenship.
Ah How v. United States, 193 U.S. 65; 48 L. Ed. 619.

Mr. Justice Holmes in delivering the opinion of the
court in the last cited case used the following langauge:

"Lew Guey offered similar evidence and a certificate of another United States commissioner of a hearing before him and an adjudication that Lew Guey had the right to remain in the United States by reason of being a citizen thereof. *** As to the certificate of the United States commissioner, offered by Lew Guey, it was merely a written statement by commissioner that a person of that name was brought before him on the usual charge, and was adjudged to have the right to remain in the United States by reason of being a citizen. Apart from the possibility that the commissioner in the present hearing was not satisfied of the identity of the party, such a statement is not the certificate of residence required by the act of 1892, and is not evidence of a judgement".
United States v. Lee Poy Dew, 119 Fed. 786; Ex parte Lung Wing Wun, 161 Fed. 211.

I did not know of the last cited case at the time of the oral argument. It is from this Distict and is exactly parallel, the decision going even farther than your Honor need go in this case. Judge Hanford holds that while a Commissioner has authority under Section 13 of the Act of 1888 (page 16 of pamphlet herewith) to decide whether or not a Chinaman is is lawfully entitled to be or remain in the United States, yet such Commissioner does not have authority in such proceeding to

"establish the status of the accused person as a citizen of the United States, entitled to all the rights, privileges, and immunities of a citizen, including the right, to be subsequently exercised, of returning to the United States after a voluntary departure, therefrom."

In short, our contention is that in refusing to accept the certificate as evidence of citizenship, the Department is only following a well established rule of law and cannot therefore be said to be abusing the discretion conferred upon it by Congress.
E B Brockway Asst U.S. Atty
